awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Exploring the Impact of Noyce Master Teaching Fellowship Programs on Teacher Retention: The Role of Motivation, Leadership, and School-Work Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national need to improve the retention and persistence of STEM teachers in high-need schools across the nation.  It will do so by studying the retention and persistence of Noyce Master Teacher Fellows compared to a control teacher population. Specifically, this Noyce Track 4 Collaborative Research project will conduct an exploratory study through a collaboration among eight universities: Rice University (lead institution), Middle Tennessee State University, University of Rochester, Southern Illinois University at Carbondale, University of Arizona, University of Louisiana-Lafayette, University of California-San Diego, and Kennesaw State University. K-12 education in the U.S. has been suffering from teacher shortages and attrition, particularly in mathematics and science disciplines and particularly in high-need schools. Investigating factors related to teacher retention and persistence is, thus, a crucial first step to increasing the positive effects of teacher retention on K-12 education. By comparing Noyce Master Teaching Fellows with a group of non-Noyce teachers with similar background characteristics, the impact of the Noyce Master Teaching Fellows programs on long-term teacher retention and persistence should become more visible. 

Building on existing research and theories related to teacher development and retention including self-efficacy, self-determination, and networks, the project intends to investigate the relation between key teacher constructs and variables (e.g., motivation, leadership skills, diversity dispositions, school-work environment, social networks, and professional background) and teacher retention and persistence. The project aims to compare Noyce Master Teaching Fellows with non-Noyce teachers, using both quantitative and qualitative methods. Results of this study have the potential to inform teacher preparation and development programs, as well as stakeholders who are trying to solve the teacher retention and persistence problems facing the nation, particularly in high-need schools and school districts. An external Advisory Board of expert scholars will provide feedback throughout the implementation of the research study. Broad dissemination of the findings is planned through Rice’s Digital Scholarship Archive, publications in academic journals, and presentations at professional conferences. To reach the public audience, articles about the project will be sent to local newspapers; and the work and its findings will be disseminated through social media outlets (e.g., website, FaceBook, Twitter). This Track 4: Research project is supported through the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program (Noyce). The Noyce program supports talented STEM undergraduate majors and professionals to become effective K-12 STEM teachers and experienced, exemplary K-12 STEM teachers to become STEM master teachers in high-need school districts. It also supports research on the persistence, retention, and effectiveness of K-12 STEM teachers in high-need school districts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF SOUTHERN ILLINOIS UNIVERSITY

por.por_cntn:
Our project was a collaboration among researchers from Rice University (lead institution), the University of Rochester, Middle Tennessee State University, University of Arizona, University of California at San Diego, University of Louisiana-Lafayette, and Kennesaw State University with two PIs at Southern Illinois University Carbondale. Working with our collaborators, we surveyed K-12 mathematics and science teachers in high-need schools from 7 regions including the west coast, Midwest, and northeast U.S. to investigate factors related to retention and persistence based upon their motivation (intrinsic value and self-efficacy for teaching), leadership skills, diversity dispositions, social networks, and school-work environment. We compared 85 teachers that had participated in one of seven long-term (five year) Noyce Master Teaching Fellowship (MTF) programs between 2012 and 2020 with 82 teachers that had not (non-MTFs), but had similar professional background, teaching preparation, certification, and experience, and professional development. We grouped the teachers into stayers (remained in the classroom teaching), leavers (left K-12 education entirely), or shifters (moved into a formal leadership role within education).

Intellectual Merit: Our research was grounded in the literature on evidence-based, effective practice in STEM teaching and learning. Specific outcomes of our project include the following:

  • 10 presentations and posters at regional and national conferences.
  • One conference proceeding describing a preliminary analysis of the project.
  • The following four peer-reviewed journal manuscripts
  1. An Instrument validation paper (accepted pending revision) in which we present our survey instrument and interview protocols designed for program evaluation and further research into STEM teacher retention and leadership.
  2. A qualitative analysis paper (in review) that examined the perspectives and experiences of 21 science and mathematics teachers in the U.S. who shifted from classroom teaching to leadership roles in their schools and districts. This study contributes knowledge to the field about educational leadership development programs and provides insight on teacher leadership from the perspectives of teachers who shift into leadership roles.
  3. A qualitative paper that analyzes pathways to leadership followed by teachers who left the classroom for leadership positions. Leaders who participated in the Noyce program credited it with multiple positive outcomes, including supporting their credibility as leaders and their confidence to lead. We found that through leadership experiences our study participants developed purpose and identity for leadership, suggesting that leadership development should be embedded in the professional development structures that all teachers experience.
  •  
    1. The main project paper arising from our survey of the 167 teachers who  participants in our research. We report that Noyce MTFs had higher levels of teaching self-efficacy and utilization of teaching and leadership networks compared to non-MTFs. Leadership engagement was positively related to shifting as Noyce MTFs who engaged in leadership training were more likely than non-MTFs to leave full time classroom teaching into formal leadership/ administration roles within K-12 education. Teaching self-efficacy was negatively associated with leaving. Elementary teachers’ teaching self-efficacy improved with shifting to a leadership position. Teachers that change position (shifters) had larger leadership network size, more bridging opportunities, and higher geographic proximity compared with teachers that stay as classroom teachers.

In summary, our project has shown:

  • Support for teacher leadership programs that help retain teachers in STEM education either in the classroom or in administrative roles (or some hybrid positions).
  • School administrators can play a key role encouraging teachers to participate in leadership activities.
  • We observed a positive reaction from teachers and education researchers about our findings at national meetings and in reviews of our written products. We’ve helped create a synergy among scholars engaged in taking this research forward.

Broader impacts. The Robert Noyce Scholarship program provides intensive long-term training in science, pedagogy and leadership. Through this project, we have systematically and methodically assessed the impact of the involvement of science and math teachers in the high-quality leadership and pedagogy activities provided during the Noyce experience. Our findings provide insight on retention and development of high-quality teachers and leaders. The diverse studies supported by this project have advanced evidence-based approaches to improving STEM education and educator development, and will inform the design of future teacher leadership programs. Our research has contributed scientific knowledge that is important in achieving societally relevant outcomes, namely improved teacher training and student outcomes. Our validated instruments are available for future applications and we anticipate broad uptake among researchers investigating teacher leadership, retention, and underlying structural, human, psychological, and social capitals.


Last Modified: 12/06/2024
Modified by: Karen S Renzaglia
